title: anet a8 easy E3D bowden extruder solution

description.text:
Hi

I was converting my anet a8 printer to E3D v6 hotend solution.
They was cheap so i bought two of them. One was installed as printer hotend and the other one left unused.
I waas searching for extruder conversion to bowden then and realized that E3D radiator perfectly fits to my extruder :)

I have tested it and it works perfecly:

  • it is full metal solution
  • cools extruder motor (becouse it is a radiator :P )
  • cooling fan was included in e3d so it can be placed easly to boost cooling
  • has PFTE tubing inside
  • can be easly removed
  • no ingerention in original extruder construction at all

Now there was a problem where to mount it. I was searched available solutions on thingverse but not found what I was looking for.... :(

...but.

There are big holes in Anet's frame at the sides. Someone heard a long time ago that they are cable ducts.. but no one uses them and no one knows what the are really for. This is perfect place to mount bowden extruder... So I have designed a mounting option.

Please test it and let me know how it works. :)
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/THE_QXR764Y" ></iframe>

There are two different files, one with a slot cut out, and one without. I use the one with the slot cut out, but I left the previous version in case it's useful.

title: E010 TX01 TX02 Camera Mount, Very lightweight!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is probably the lightest printable camera mount available for the Eachine E010 Tiny Whoop!
It's 1/3 to 1/10 the weight of other mounts available!
Confirmed to fit the Furibee F36 as well!

If anyone try it out, please do share a make or comment if there's anything you think needs to be improved, all feedback is highly appreciated!

[WEIGHT OF MOUNT]
0 degree: ~2.3g
10 degree: ~2.5g
20 degree: ~2.7g

[MOUNTING INSTRUCTIONS]
1) Remove plastic cover of the E010.
2) Remove screws of PCB and remove the foam padding under the front part of the PCB
3) Push the E010 camera mount around the top of the PCB until holes line up.
4) Attach PCB to the frame again with the screws.
5) Put a piece of tape under the camera PCB to isolate it.
6) Push the camera onto the holder.
7) Connect camera to the power source.
8) Go fly!

[COMPATIBLE QUAD]
Eachine E010: www.banggood.com/Eachine-E010-Mini-2_4G-4CH-6-Axis-Headless-Mode-RC-Quadcopter-RTF-p-1066972.html

[COMPATIBLE CAMERAS]
TX01 (25mW): www.banggood.com/Eachine-TX01-Super-Mini-AIO-5_8G-40CH-25MW-VTX-600TVL-14-Cmos-FPV-Transmitter-p-1088374.html
TX02 (200mW): www.banggood.com/Eachine-TX02-Super-Mini-AIO-5_8G-40CH-200mW-VTX-600TVL-14-Cmos-FPV-Camera-p-1088368.html

[UPDATES]
2017-01-11: New improved version released, Angles 0deg, 10deg and 20deg available.
2017-01-10: Release of first version.

This is the 1 and also the top shaft and also the bottom shaft, If you do not use a raft then it will not stick to the build plate as well to get the proper resolution. For these parts you should try and use the highest resolution that you have, It will help with the threads.

title: Monoprice Maker Select V2 Fan Guard

description.text:
This is a guard for the print head cooling fans on the Monoprice Maker Select V2, modeled in Autodesk Inventor Professional 2016. Theoretically, this piece should also work for the Wanhao Duplicator i3/Cocoon Create. I don't have either of those printers, though, so I can't say for sure that the fans are the same.

It push-fits directly into the two unused screw holes on each fan. For the guards to fit with the out-of-the-box screw arrangement, you need one of each guard.

Note: it does make the fans a bit louder due to slightly restricting the airflow, but the noise increase isn't significant compared to how loud the printer is anyway.

Proxy models compatible with Games Workshop's Epic Armageddon to represent your Astra Militarum Imperial Guard infantry formations.

Epic Armageddon is out of print and the models can be hard to find. Use these to sub for your games.

UPDATE: 311009AUG17 After trying several times to print the original files I've followed another modeler's suggestion and increased X and Y dimensions of the figures by 20%, and Z by about 10% to preserve the proportions. Test print of a single figure was successful.

So I've seen this made a time or two and I've had a go at it myself. When I make designs for Shapeways I'm designing for an SLS process, and sometimes for SLA. PLA extrusion methods seem to be a little hit and miss at this scale.

description.text:
My 5 year old daughter needed help when getting those nasty 4+ in the UNO card game. Printing this cheered her up and we are now able to play for a lot longer.

Besides, I had to train my use of the "follow me" tool in sketchup and the excellent plugin from Fredo6 - Round Corner. I uploaded the sketchup file as well just for fun. Note that for the follow me tool to work properly I draw my things 10x bigger than real life and then scale them at the end.

I know the do-not-tip-over-legs are not symmetric. But this was drawn in like 10 minutes so bare with me!

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: Cuisinart EM-200 Espresso Machine Extended Steam Lever

description.text:
The current lever is very difficult to turn, this lever slips right over the current one and adds the leverage needed to turn on or off steam/water.

*Note the lever hole is asymmetric, it is larger on one end to slide further onto the current lever.

Installation:

First way: Press the lever on. It was designed for exact press fit onto the current lever. It should hold very well. If you are worried it will fall off, use epoxy like gorilla glue.

Second way (in addition to glue): I designed the part with pocket holes for M3 cap bolts. Press fit the lever on, mark the holes, remove lever, drill holes, replace lever, install bolts. Try to use shorter bolts, this should keep the lever in place.

I am currently using it as just press fitted on. It has been working well.

Thank!

description.text: This is a blender that works with a drill, razor blades, and a can of a canned vegetable/fruit such as a Dole pineapple can or a large/wide can of tomatoes. The can works as a cover, so you'll need to drill a hole through the middle of the bottom of it. You will also need a 1/4" threaded rod and appropriate nuts to attach the cylinder to the drill. You will also need machine screws and nuts to attach the clips. Use acetone or Gorilla Glue to attach the clips to the Cylinder.

Pretty simple. I first printed the cylinder and 3 copies of the clips. Then, I joined the clips (with razor blades inside them) to the cylinder with acetone and Gorilla Glue. Then I got the empty can of tomatoes and drilled a hole in the middle of the bottom. Next, I got the threaded rod and pit the cylinder on the end of the rod. Attach it to the chuck of a drill and there you have it.

A spirograph! for a 3D printer.
I used Catarina's Spur Gear Script for a lot of this, then tore out the most interesting parts and put in my own. Thanks/sorry!
Included are OpenSCAD files so you can change pretty much anything. OpenSCAD is so cool.
If you make one I would love to see it! My 3D printer is unfortunately not done yet. 
I couldn't make the holes on the gear evenly spaced; they get farther and farther apart from each other, like a curve. It would be great if someone could show me how to fix this. Also, I'm not entirely sure the holes are big enough, but they should be pretty roomy. If not, tell me and edit the OpenSCAD file!
Oh, I also put an .stl of a weird little gear that I made with Catarina's script in. It'll make a design though!
added: option to make the stator a ring instead of a square, but don't use it yet. There's a weird half solid thing filling a couple of the teeth that i figured was rendering weirdness, but thingiverse is rendering it like that too. Any ideas? edit - it appears that the rendering weirdness is a thin sheet - you might be able to cut it off. Still, I don't know if it will work. caveat maker.
added: aron says the fit is too tight, so I edited the defaults on the .scad and changed the .stl. Also, before, the number of teeth on the spirograph was twice the number of teeth on the gear, so it made an oval. Fixed that too. Thanks aron!
added: changed the addenda and dedenda for a (hopefully) better fit. No big deal, though.

Print the first part. Print the second part. Place pen in hole. Rotate gear with pen in it. Have hypotrochoidal fun!
Some notes on making compatible rotors (gears) and stators (frames):
You want the diametral pitch (not to be confused with pitch diameter,  the nominal diameter for a gear) of the rotor and the stator to be equal. Diametral pitch is number of teeth over pitch diameter. For example, in the defaults for the openSCAD script, the number of teeth of the stator is 48 and the pitch diameter is 72. The diametral pitch is 48 / 72 = 2 / 3. Coincidentally (?), the number of teeth of the rotor is 22 and the pitch diameter  is 33, giving a diametral pitch of 2 / 3, so these will fit.
In a perfect universe, gears with the same teeth width will mesh, but I'm guessing printer irregularities and shrinking plastic make them too tight. You might want to make the tooth widths of the rotor a little smaller than that of the stator. 
Also, as aron pointed out, if the diameter (or teeth number - the are/should be proportional) of the rotor is half that of he stator, you get an oval. There's a lot of math going on here with greatest common factors and whatnot. Try experimenting with different proportions and prime numbers to get different patterns.

Took me a while to get something that would work properly with my Rep Rap Guru i3 printer and the BLTouch sensor. All the other mounts were too close to the print bed. This mount is just about perfect if you max out the height. Future model will have and additional 10mm of adjustment to just to make sure.

Version 2 increases the adjustment to 30mm and an additional file with a fan guard option.

Version 3 is the latest and best working version to date. I printed it with ABS and 100% infill to make it more sturdy. I added a couple of holes near the base of the BLTouch mount for a small ziptie to hold the sensor a bit more stable as I was getting variations in the sensor height. The base is also thicker adding to the overall rigidity. A fan guard was also added. So far this version has proven to be more stable and produce more accurate sensor/bed leveling results over the previous versions.

--UPDATE--
Added version 6 of the mount that I am using now. It's a bit less bulky and allows for easier addition of a blower fan for the hotend. It mounts to the stepper motor and uses an M5 screw to hold it in place. I like it better than the original.

comments.text: Working with STL files is a bit of a pain. In most programs all you can do is add or remove from the surface of the model. author: Annesocalypse

description.text:
Since I met 3D technology in 2010 dreamed of my own 3D printer, and my first project was ... hydraulic turbines. I have a good reason: a farm with 16000m2 with a small flow of water, my goal is an open source micro-hydro installation. My first step was to build the turbine. When I finally made my first 3D printer in 2013/07/20 did some searching in Thingiverse and tried several turbines. I was not satisfied with the results. So I decided to design my own turbine.
Took Pelton design, with some changes to make it easier to print. It is made in two parts that fit. The center has a hole for an 8mm threaded rod secured with nuts and washers. It has 4 screws holding the two parts well and make it more robust. It has 18cm diameter and was designed with Sketchup:Make. I'll publish the progress in my website www.permaculturaaralar.com

Print both parts and join together with 4 screws and nuts.  
Introduce the axis and fit it with nuts and washers.  
I work usually with PLA, So I printed in this material. This piece is exposed to water and moisture. I'm testing durability with PLA, perhaps you prefer print in ABS to improve that issue.

comments.text: Looks like a nice wheel, but it is not a pelton design.  To be a pelton (please correct me if I'm wrong), the bucket would have to split the stream and transfer the energy by redirecting the water 90 degrees.
comments.author: LinuxSneaker

comments.text: You're right, it's not a pure pelton design, only has a resemblance. In my farm I need a pelton design but its shape could be difficult to print (look the other designs in thingiverse and you'll understand me). So, I made an easy design, divided in two parts, both of them have a great and flat surface and are easier to print. I didn't explain this issue when I uploaded the stl file, your comment is an opportunity to clear it. Anyway, it works!!    Thx,
comments.author: LinuxSneaker

comments.text: very nice. My new printer I am building will be able to print close to 400mm square so 'i am going to scale this up to 380mm diameter. Very excited nice design

author: jamestait65

print_settings.Notes:: I used PLA from DasFilament.de to print the parts for my antenna.

description.text:
With these 3D printed Parts and some other materials, you can build a YAGI antenna for almost any frequency! And that only for about 20€!

The Antenna is designed after the well-known guide "7db for 7 bucks" and is used to calculate the lenghts and spacing of the Elements. Also, use the guide to determine the material amount.

Beside the 3d printed driver and the two elements you need the following materials:

  • Weldingrod Ø 2mm
  • Cable with connector (i used RG-59 with 75ohm with BNC)
  • 2x Carbon Tubes Ø 12mm
  • 4x Clamps for Ø 12mm Carbon Tubes
  • 4x m3 self tapping screws (only for the grip)

UPDATE 13.2.2017:

Added a printable grip/handle including a option to secure the carbon boom when the Antenna is folded in half.

Printer:

Zonestar D810

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

You only need Supports for the Driver itself.

The Elements (Director / Reflector) must be printed upside down.

The grip i printed with the boom clip () on the bed.

I used PLA from DasFilament.de to print the parts for my antenna.

Assembly

Before following these steps: Read 7db for 7 bucks

  1. Install the aluminum clamps on the plastic parts you printed
  2. Cut the welding rods to the right length and install them
  3. Install the bottom carbon tube in the driver
  4. Route the Cable through the carbon tube and solder the Cable on the two welding rods inside the driver
  5. Install the top carbon tube
  6. Install the director and reflector on the carbon tubes

comments.text: Any chance of getting the design files to scale for other bands?
comments.author: Whichway

comments.text: There is no need for scaling the parts, you can use them for any frequencie you like.
comments.author: Whichway

comments.text: Actually, I'm interested in 70cm. Since the elements are a lot shorter, I wanted to shorten the wire arms so there's not so much lossy dialectric right on the wires. The boom parts are fine.
comments.author: Tysonpower

comments.text:
The arms are only 15cm across, so it will not cover that much of the element.
Also the plastic will not effect the gain at all (even when it will be so minor, that it's not noticeable)
comments.author: Whichway

comments.text: Ok, thanks.
comments.author: Tysonpower

print_settings.Notes:: It is amazing the difference this makes on leveling.

title: Zonestar P802NR2 Table Leveling Knob 10.8 MM hole size

description.text:
I printed krapapock's part and the hole was 10 and I needed a 10.8 so designed one based on his design. So measure your leveling nut and print what works best for you. Oh, I put a mesh with hole for screw threads to pass through. B-)

One other thing, the original nut that comes with the machine must be squeezed into my design. I get it started and use my teeth to push it in then wack it with a Thwack hammer B-p. Use your own technique to get it to fit.
Not sure about Anet let me know.

Recumbent Lion, Loutraki 570-560 B.C., Nye Carlsberg Glyptotek (Copenhagen, Denmark). Made with Memento Beta (now Remake) from AutoDesk.

The lion rests on a plinth carved, with the animal, out of a single block. The head is rendered frontally. The motif had its antecedents in the Near East, where the lion symbolized strength and high social status. The light marks on the head are traces of the sculpture´s original paint.

For more update, please follow @GeoffreyMarchal on Twitter.

remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi (Model B) case with 75mm VESA mount

remixed_from.author: 0110-M-P
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi 3, Pi 2, and Model B+ case with VESA mounts and more

title: Geeetech GT2560 housing lid with integrated Pi 3 case

description.text:
This is a remix of the top for the GT2560 case and the VESA case for the Raspberry Pi 3. I couldn't find anything of this sort on Thingiverse, so I took parts from what I liked from other things and put them together.

The Pi case bottom was merged with the GT2560 case lid and a few holes punched in it for 40mm fans and another below the Pi. The idea with this piece is to put the two fans directly over the stepper drivers on the board. I may need to do further tweaks to the Pi base, the SD card may not fit right and it may be the wrong way around or have a problem with the X axis stepper as it goes up and down.

I took the top and removed the decorations and display connector holes and put a hole for a 40mm fan. This may not be necessary, if you decide not to use it, then the lid I remixed from will work just fine.

Maybe too many fans. If you want a version without the holes, let me know. It doesn't have the hex pattern any more though, so it's not as pretty.

I need to reorient the top case but if printed top on the plate, will print just fine.

Thankfully both designers made the STEP files available, so I was able to load everything into Fusion 360 and do the edits from there. The operations were simple, remove elements I didn't want, and general drag and drop for moving stuff around.

title: Flexicoil Truck for the EMD SW1500
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Nasa EMD SW1500 Switcher I want to use to build my Nasa train has Flexicoil Trucks. Barspin's model (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:916416) is provided with Type A trucks.
So I've designed new trucks (actually just the side frames). I've added slightly bigger wheels to match the size of the ones used on the actual SW1500.

Printer:

Vertex K8400 and Prusa I3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 and 0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I've printed the side frames at 0.2 mm but the details will be more accurate if printed at 0.1 mm.
Everything printed in ABS.

The small pieces are glued on the frame and the frame on the SW1500 truck assembly.

The brake pipes are way oversized (hard to print a smaller diameter) ; it would be better to replace them with something smaller like a piece of copper wire.

I've designed the wheels with semi circular axle holes. I've filed the end of the axles accordingly. It prevent the wheels from slipping on the axles as the torque is quite important.
I you want to use a round axle you can bore the hole with a 3 mm bit from the inner side of the wheel : the first 2 mm are circular.

description.text:

I printed this 180 degrees from what the uploaded STL file shows. The only thing touching the base was part of the ring. Therefore, there was quite a bit of support structure required. I did this so that I could finish the print with white PLA to highlight the name.

I had to clean out a little bit of PLA from the indented area as well as the slit that you put the paper through. Overall, it wasn't bad though.

Note this is an Australian based store so this exact item may not be available in your country.

https://www.jaycar.com.au/60-minute-fast-charger-with-usb-port/p/MB3561

This can be used to keep the charger and the adaptor together for storage, I intended to use it to have the entire thing plug into the wall while this works it is only just holding on via the power outlet however on the floor in a power board it works just fine.
This style means it can easily be separated and used that way as well.

Printed on its side no support is required, raft only of your machine requires this, the Up MIni does but a machine using PLA onto BuildTak I would go raftless.
Very little cleanup should be required, check the holes for the cable ties are clear and other dags or the like are removed.

description.text:
My family and I have been sick as dogs this week. We use Charmin Ultra Soft as our facial tissue, so there are toilet paper rolls all over the house. I designed this so we can mount it to the wall with two large command strips. The size is just right so that when you pull slowly the TP unrolls, but when you pull fast it breaks making it so you can grab TP with one hand. I am not sure how it will fit in other TP rolls, but it works perfect in charmin.

Update
I printed another one of these in low res and noticed that there was a gap in the print. This has been fixed in the new stl file (removed the old).

Update
Ok, so my toddler basically hung on one of these and ripped the holder and some plaster off the wall (yeah!). So, I made a screw-in version of this. I designed these to be used with the TOGGLER self screwing anchors which can hold ~80lbs each and I highly recommend. I also made up a template for marking and spacing the screw holes.

http://www.toggler.com/products/snapskru/overview.php

Hi,

I had some problems with my vulcanus v2. First I could not find any "46° Parts". But I could extract them from the fusion 360 Files.
Second I could not use the "X-carriage"-Parts with my cheap E3D-V6 from AliExpress. So I modified This Part for the usage with longer bowden holder. I hope it could be helpfull to finish this printer.

All stuff is printed with PLA

Update: z-endstop added. I changed the endstop to get it more stable on the z-axis

Update 2: The belt holder did not work well for me. I had some slips which caused print failures. So I decided to redesign the holder and the idler. It seems to work better but I did not test ist for a long time.Use cable ties. The upper part of the carriage holds well hence it stays like it is. If someone have experienced also problems with it leave a comment.

comments.text: Hi, I used different Hot Ends. I experienced best results with ptfe-nozzle threats. All metal are not so good. The one I am using now in Vulcanus was from shop "Kee Pang" but they seem mostly the similar. I am using 0.4 nozzle and printing ABS on aluminium-bed with silicon heater and use 3dlac, first layer on 100 degree, further on 90. I leveld the bed during the prints trying to get filament sticked on the bed. Sine I switched to ptfe threats I had no jams at all. Bigger problems where lost steps. I still Use the chip stepper (4988) with arduino mega. Now I am cooling them with flexible fan holder wich I posted on thingiverse today.

I made a newer version of this - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2781475

Just about any 40 x 10 mm fan should work, but the one I used specifically is from Digi-Key - https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/qualtek/FAD1-04010CBMW11/Q612-ND/2600059.

title: Logitech C270 Webcam Mount for VORON, 2020 Extrusion
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A sturdy, no-hardware Logitech C270 webcam mount for the VORON. Also compatible with any 2020 extrusions having 6mm slot widths. The C270 is ubiquitous on Amazon and directly compatible with OctoPrint. Please heed the print guidelines below!

Printer:

MZBot VORON

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print slowly (30mm/s) to capture mechanical mounting features! 0.4mm nozzle, 2 perimeters, 2 layers top/bottom. For best results, be mindful of support material orientation on the clips.

Installation

1) Remove supports from mid-sections of the 2020 clip and webcam mount point.
2) Remove the C270's stock mount by peeling away two rubber covers on opposite sides of the hinge with a small screwdriver. Remove the screw and push out the exposed pin.
3) Reassemble the C270 onto the VORON mount using the same pin and screw that you just removed. Only one orientation is correct; mind the keying features. It is an intentionally snug fit.
4) Seat the 2020 clip on the bottom face of the aluminum extrusion.
5) Pull the gantry upward with some force. You should achieve a solid "click" and a firm hold.
6) Slide the gantry to the desired horizontal position.

A) If needed, adjust the webcam focus to the hotend positioned in the middle of the XY plane.

Removal

1) Using two #2 flat screwdrivers, simultaneously pry upward on the top clips until the gantry pops downward.
2) Pull down on the gantry gently until the clips are free.

Design

Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360 for the VORON project.

description.text:
This is the model my son and I created for boy scout pinewood derby.  It is our first car and we haven't raced it yet so I have no idea how it will do.  No effort was made to make it particularly fast; my son just wanted it to look cool. 

Included here is only a body which is intended to be mounted on top of a simple 'I' frame car.  

I've sliced it into 5 separate printable pieces to avoid printing overhangs.  The parts glue together nicely using acetone to 'melt' the abs,  and with some bondo and sanding it looks like one complete unit.  The bottom piece of the body will need to be glued on after the body has been placed onto the car's frame.   

I'll add photos when time allows. 

I've also included the profile drawings in case you want to cut it out of a block of wood.  

Note, you'll need two blocks of wood glued together.

.

2. I used a dremel to gut out the entire inside of the body leaving only a thin shell and a place to screw mount the frame.  This was necessary to give plenty of room to adjust wheel and weight placement. 

3. The front of the body extends a little too far in front of the front wheels and may hit the track at the bottom of the curve.  I'm not certain because I didn't get to race it.  To address this concern, I put a shim between the body and the frame to raise the body a bit. 

If I have time, I will go back and try to stretch the x-axis and see if I can make the frame fit around a full size car. >

Robo 3D

15%

We used Fusion 360 sculpting mode to create the design and then the modeling environment to make final technical adjustments.

description.text:
Update 1/20/17:

A couple of people had mentioned how big the guide was and how it really didn't need to be that big and thick. So I have also made a 'mini' version of the guide. I call it, the Thin Guide! The thin filament guide is much smaller and thinner than the original but still fits the printer great and still works like a charm! It also uses way less filament and prints much faster! So, if your looking for a guide without all that baggage, then try it out! Let me know what you think!

A remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1657012 designed to lay flat on the print bed so that it requires less supports to print. I also wanted something a little sleeker and more simplistic design wise.

This filament guide is designed to fit the Monoprice Maker Select 3D printer and all its relatives (Wanhao Duplicator i3, etc). The guide clips onto the top of the frame and is easily moveable.

While many other filament guides for the i3 are designed to be screwed in along side the filament spool holder, this one is designed to go on without any needed hardware. The reasoning behind this? Because I have my filament spool holder mounted on the control box currently (and it will be mounted on top of the enclosure soon) and wanted something that fit on the printer without needing to buy screws for it.

This is my first design ever, and I'm pretty dang proud of it.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed my prototype that I use now at .01mm layer height and 20% infill. You are free to change those up at your own whim and will. I like using .01 layer height for the look, and the 20% layer height was to help with the top/bottom surfaces. If you can get away with using less infill go right ahead!

I designed this all using Fusion 360. Since this was my first ever 3D model it took me quite a while to get used to the interface and different tools. I am so grateful for all the online communities and posts that helped me solve my problems and figure out how to accomplish this.

I wasn't able to find a great way to edit the .stl model from the original, so I ended up designing everything from scratch while borrowing measurements and ideas from the original. It was definitely a great learning experience.

description.text:
Here is a minor remix of Fichthorn's Spirit of St. Louis. I've split the plate into parts for three colors - white for the fuselage, wings, tail, and struts, silver for the front part of the plane and propeller, and black for the wheels and engine.

Also, since I have a common 200x200 buildplate, I've scaled the model up, to 25% larger than his original, and re-arranged a few parts to accommodate these changes.

Please note that the gaps between some parts are very thin, as it's designed to snap togetgher. You'll need a very well calibrated printed and good filament to reproduce this well enough, and you'll probably need to make use of your hobby knife here and there.

After printing, there are numerous support bits that need to be removed, and some knife work will be needed to clean up the bridging inside the four square holes on the underside of the front wing.

Assemble the fuselage onto the front struts first, then add the back strut, and the front wing, taking care to snap the struts into the holes in the wing - they will be a tight fit.

Press the back wing onto the back end of the plane, with the wide cut facing away from the fuselage and the side that was on the build plate facing up. Then, press the tail into place.

At this point, glue the existing parts together. Since you'll need to squeeze and press the glue into the nooks and crannies of the model, you'll want to use something that takes a while to dry, so that you can cleanly wipe off any excess as needed. Superglue is okay for the front struts, but not recommended for the fuselage seam.

Next, trim the flared projection on the back of the propeller, and trim the inside of the matching projection on the front of the silver front end pieces, so that the frontend pieces fit flatly together when the propeller is installed. With the two pieces held together, snap the engine on, with the flared side away from the frontend.

Press the propeller into the hole - this part will be tricky, as the flare on the propeller shaft is a tight fit. Glue the engine and frontend pieces together, but leave the propeller loose. Glue the assembly to the front of the fuselage, with the steeper slope facing up.

Finally, snap the wheels into place, flat sides toward the struts.

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

This model "needs" supports, but it already comes with support objects as supplied by Fichthorn. You could also "split" the model and delete those in favor of what your slicer provides, if you want.

The pictured model was printed with Atomic "Bright White", "Metallic Silver" and "Deep Black" PLA. I printed it with 0.2 mm layer thickness, but in retrospect, 0.1 mm would have looked much better on the fuselage.

description.text:
This model functions as a large-sized monster when fitted into its base and as an alternate insert designed to fit into the Scrying Pool. These were designed for any tabletop RPG or wargame, or for Wayfarer Tactics, our fast, modular (as in "fully customizable") miniature gaming rules. If you want to check it out, it's totally free here on our site, so give it a download!.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

The character models shown are from Wargames Foundry.

Enjoy!

title: Stereographic projection maze - prototype
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It's actually the front of Stereographic projection maze. If you use it to project, it's not as accurate as Stereographic projection maze. The reason is this prototype just connects two points to form a line with some modifications of the line thickness. Besides, the generated model of this prototype looks weird if you specify a small maze size, such as the stereographic_maze2_5x5.stl.

This is, however, a simple way to demonstrate how to implement stereographic projection.

Even though a more accurate Stereographic projection maze grew out of this, I still published it. That's because my daughter said the generated model itself has a special style and i have the same feeling, too.

Find my things about stereographic projection in stereographic_projection.

  • OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

Do you want to know how to create mazes with OpenSCAD? The following documents may help.

  • Manual maze
  • Binary tree algorithm
  • Random maze

My library dotSCAD has a stereographic_extrude module. You can use it to create a thing of stereographic projection easily.

  • stereographic_extrude

author: PandaLuv

title: Best Damn Tie Holder - Invisible Tie Fastener Device
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an invisible tie fastener. Just button it onto the existing buttons of your shirt and it slips through the keeper loop on the back of the front tie blade. Keeps everything nice and tighty with a clean look.

I printed it in Nijaflex, and would recommend printing in some kind of flexible filament.

There are two stls, one of them is 2mm thick, the other is a little slimmer at 1mm thick for a more flexible tie buddy. But both of them are pretty flexible.

Depending on the spacing of the buttons on your shirt this may not fit all shirts, however it seems to work on all the shirts I have, even though they are from a variety of brands, the spacing must be standardized.

Sorry the pictures kinda suck.

Notes:

You really want to use the 30mm but i used the 20mm in the picture and fixed my mistake. You need it wider to cover the cutout hole because of the aux cord and power. Print the 30mm. Push the dot through the back of the wall plate to where it is almost flush but not covering the led ring. Then hot glue the back.

** Before you print flip the design so it prints down and use support for the screw holes for a nice clean surface!**

comments.author: thenewguy6

title: Flashlight Clamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Small flashlight clamp, designed to attach a AAA flashlight to a skateboard deck. The flashlight works as the hinge and is needed to hold the clamp together. It's inspired by and works Similarly to the Kant Twist* clamps that I use with my BoXZY CNC. There's also a one piece version that can be used as a normal clamp.

I used support material on all of the pictured prints and used thread taps to add the M4 and M5 threads.

Parts:

  • ThorFire AAA Flashlight* - 13.6mm
  • County Comm AAA flashlight (not sure which version) - 14.5mm
  • M4 button socket cap screw - 10mm or shorter
  • M5 screw - 25mm or shorter

Printer:

  • Eustathios

Design:

  • Onshape - check out the branches for the different versions

Filaments:

  • Atomic Filament Pastel Lilac PLA
  • Atomic Filament Maize Yellow PLA
  • Atomic Filament Pearlescent Blue PLA
  • Atomic Filament Glow in the Dark PETG
  • Atomic Filament Transparent Aqua PETG

*affiliate link

comments.text:

remixed_from.author: Lifeburn
remixed_from.title: Cavern Floor with Pillars - OpenForge Compatible

description.text:
Did a plane cut to remove the bubble pools (thank you LIfeburn) from base for use with other terrain such as wargaming mats, rigid insulation / neoprene mat cavern tiles, etc.

The cavern tile in photo was created with DM Scotty's Tilescapes #14 technique (on youtube -- can search for it).

Other scatter terrain is Hirst Arts Water Cavern Mold #82.

There is a small hole under one of the pillars / bubble pools on one of them, after I plane cut it with Mesh Mixer. I printed with supports, no problems.

Base Coat: Espresso Brown.
Sponge / Stipple Brush Coat (Light): Burnt Sienna
Spong / Stipple Brush Coat (Heavier): Cocoa (some dry brushing on 2nd pass)
Dry Brush with very dry brush: Cocoa mixed with Snow White.

(All Americana Paints mentioned above except for Espresso -- that's Home Depot).

title: Rogue One Star Wars Cassian's Blaster Side Detail

description.text:
This is the side detail for a 1 to 1 blaster like Cassian's in Rogue one.
The base for the blaster is an M4A1 airsoft rifle.
You will need 4 of these for the rifle.
I included a full version if you have a printer that can make it,
There is also a 3/4 version that will print on a flat bed.

print_settings.Notes:: 100% "concentric" pattern infill for the throwing arm and C-clips, 100% infill in any pattern for support A, and 10% on everything else seems to work fine.

description.text:
This is a modified version of thing:1381027.

I try to take a purist route and don't think a 3d printed object should need glue or welding if at all possible. I've modified it to snap the supports onto the base, and to use c-clips to hold the supports together. I tried to use split snap posts for the connection between support A and support B, but the layer adhesion isn't good enough at this size, and the tabs just break. So I added the C-Clips, and they hold with plenty of strength.

Note the orientation of the throwing arm to Support A during assembly, shown in the first image. The throwing arm is installed in that position and then wound before installing the base. Assembly is the same as the video at the original thing except for snapping and using the c-clips instead of welding with a soldering iron or gluing.

I also modified the size of the hole in the spring to provide less clearance, and therefore less chance of it spinning passed the corners.

Because the ammo basket requires bridging in the through-hole, the insertion of the throwing arm may be rough, but should fit. But if it doesn't fit for some reason, wedging the basket on works just as well (which is what I did before I expanded the clearance).

When printing, I printed Support A, the spring/throwing arm, and the c-clips solid. I set the infill pattern and top and bottom layer patterns to "concentric" to add as much spring and as little chance of fracturing as possible. Everything else I printed at a 10% infill.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

100% and 10%

Notes:

100% "concentric" pattern infill for the throwing arm and C-clips, 100% infill in any pattern for support A, and 10% on everything else seems to work fine.

title: Anet A8 Electronics Case (mainboard, octopi, step-down converter, relay and fan.)

description.text:
This is a remix/overhaul of a previous case for the Anet A8. i have cleaned up the cases mounting and other areas. changed the cable opening and moved a bit of the mounting locations. i have added a step-down converter mount and mounting location under the raspberry pis mounting location. the arrow on this mount goes with the arrow on the converter. I have also added fan mounting and covers. one set will work with the fans included mounting screws with 2 attaching the fan to the case and 2 attaching the cover to the fan. the other set needed a M3x25mm screws to go from the cover to the case cover with the fan wedged between.

EDIT: V8 i have added a hole on the bottom right of the case (when its standing up) for the left z axis motors wires.

Components recommended:

  • To control the printer. Raspberry PI 3 Model B
  • To allow the raspberry pi to power the printer on and off Channel DC 5V Relay Switch Module for Arduino Raspberry Pi ARM AVR
  • This is for the Pi to control the printer. there isnt much room for a long cable, or you can cut the included cable down to size and splice together. 6 Inch Micro USB Cable
  • To drop power from 12V PSU to 5v for Raspberry Pi SMAKN® 5pcs Mini MP1584EN Step-down Power DC-DC 3A Ultra Adjustable LM2596
  • The full cover is sized for a slim 80mm fan. As i wanted as low of a profile as i could. Cooler Master Sleeve Bearing 80mm Slim Silent Fan
  • x20 M3x6mm Self Tapping Screws. M3 Black Alloy Steel Allen Hex Socket Cap Head Self Tapping Screws
  • x4 M3x16mm Self Tapping Screws. (can be longer)
  • x4 M3x25mm Self Tapping Screws For Fan. (8 of these screws if you dont want to order 4x16mm and 4x25mm) (10) M3x25mm Hex Socket Tapping Button Head Black
  • m3 tapping hex
  • Cable Sleeving
  • eBay for anything else

author: attackmanz

description.text:
This is a threaded ball screw and nut. Due to the large surface area, this threaded rod can withstand quite a bit of force before the plastic bearings start to deform.

Uses:
M3 screws 60mm long (qty 5)
M3 nuts (qty 5)
6mm BB's (qty: too many to count)

3 printed parts:
threaded rod (threaded rod can be printed multiple times)
nut
nut cap

adding the BB's:
1) fill in the bottom nut full
2) attach the cap
3) leave the nut slightly off of the screw and push the rest of the balls upward into the nut. It doesn't have to be completely packed.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

20%-80%

comments.text: What kind of opposing vertical force could this support?
comments.author: AndresMM

comments.text: It depends on the type of plastic, infill, etc.  So I'm go to say it can support 7, exactly 7 before breaking.
comments.author: AndresMM

comments.text: I actually probably will. It will take a couple of weeks though. Did you use PLA for the part that resisted 30 pounds?
comments.author: Fillitup309

comments.text: I used ABS because its easier to sand, smooth with acetone than PLA (and it was in the printer at that time).  ABS can be lubricated with oil. PLA seems to only run smoother with water as the lubricant. (way more testing would be needed on that topic).  PLA will work just fine.  Prints smoother and has better layer adhesion.  But both have to same relative strength.  When I print with ABS I use a heated chamber, PLA I don't.
comments.author: AndresMM

comments.text: I'm very happy with this creation and can see myself actually using it in my projects.  It moves very smoothly and seems likely to be very durable considering there is no sliding in any load bearing areas.  (there is some some sliding of the balls along the channels internal to the nut but not with much load.  Even at .2 mm layers this worked well.  I did have to sand the outer edges of the threaded rod to make it a bit smaller and able to fit inside the nut well enough to be low friction.
comments.author: foxpup

comments.text:
The original solidworks file is in: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:567744
(I will put it in here to). I have used the sleeve idea on a pipe. I just sanded the ends smooth and butted the segments together and glued them. I found the having pegs to align the threads just made it harder to get the thread continuous.
I do plan on adding more variations of the threaded ball screws. But each ball nut is not straight forward and all unique to the thread. If you have a specific application I can see if I have time to modify the thread to fit a need
comments.author: foxpup

comments.text:
I have just finished printing the nut on a ROBO and it has come out perfect needing next to no cleaning up. The file size presented no problem, I reckon the extra polygons helped with the quality. The cap is now under construction as I type this and the screw will come to fruition later tonight. Not sure how I will load the BB's, something to look forward to tomorrow. I will add end caps to the screw to prevent the nut from coming off and spilling the balls everywhere. I have also considered an attachment to add a chuck to make something resembling an Archimedes drill.
Pictures to be posted on completion.
comments.author: 58webbing

comments.text: go to hear.  As for the BB's.... 1) fill in the bottom nut full.... 2) attach the cap.... 3) leave the nut slightly off of the screw and push the rest of the balls upward into the nut.  It doesn't have to be completely packed.
comments.author: 58webbing

comments.author: bernbout

comments.text: High Resolution to maintain tolerance = butt lot of polygons.  0.1mm polygons size (3 thousands tolerance).  I can upload a low resolution part but the ball may not move smoothly though the channels (if at all ). I would have to add more slop (backlash) to make the screw and balls mesh.
comments.author: bernbout

comments.text: There are actually two things you can and SHOULD do.

author: bsnowie

title: MakerFarm i3v Print Cooling Fan Mounts

description.text:
I measured an existing printed X carriage side mount to make the basic shape for this fan mount. I lengthened it and angled it to support the mounting of a set of Lulzbot TAZ 6 cooling fan ducts and standard 40mm fans. Some slight modification of the fan ducts might need to be done in order to clear hot end wiring and extruder nozzle heater block. This addition of fan mounts and ducts greatly reduced the edge warping I was experiencing while printing PLA due to over cooling of generally directed cooling fan air blowing all over one side of the print.

You will have to slightly drill out the holes for screws. In my case, I drilled out for m3 screws. Some slight filing for an M3 nut trap for mounting.

Being a beginner in Fusion 360, I stumbled my way through various tutorials on YouTube in order to come up with this mount. I drew it for only one side and mirrored it as appropriate in Cura to make a matching Left and Right hand side. Both are supplied here as well as the .STEP and .f3d files.

author: deweycox

print_settings.Notes:: These parts are mostly hidden so cosmetics are not really a concern, print them as fast or as slow as you like.  Just be sure to compare measurements of your printer rods and the parts prior to disassembling in case some scaling is needed.  You can save having to reassemble/disassemble your printer more than once.  A little slop in the z screw hole can still provide significant improvements as I saw in my earlier versions of this part.  Ideally this should fit any Maylan M150 printer and possibly the wanhoo i3 as well. Additionally you can loosen the z screw nut on the carriage after reassembling your printer to relieve any tension that may be on the z screw after installing the parts, this should also help to realign the z screw and improve print quality.

title: Maylan M150 Z Axis Screw Stabilizer

description.text:
UPDATE: Before and after photos White part is before upgrade with noted "ringing" in the print from z wobble. Black figure is from after upgrade notice how smooth the object is, there is light from above to try and provoke a shadow to bring out the z wobble. I will add additional "After" photos as prints are made.

Note: These parts likely only work with the Maylan M150 3D printer, however if you have a similar model that you were able to use these parts on please let me know so I can update this info

This is a stabilizer for the Z Axis Screw. I recommend printing the z axis stabilizer kit first to acquire a true 90 degree z axis. After installing the kit my printer continued to suffer from z wobble, at first i thought it to be a bent Z rod however while moving the z axis I could see the lead screw swaying from side to side as it spun and was not bent. I designed these parts to stabilize the Z Screw and prevent swaying as the z axis moves, thus reducing or even eliminating z wobble in your prints. There are many options for similar parts however I did not come across any for the M150 Maylan 3D printer.

Recommendations: Measure your posts (support rod and z screw) both the outer distance and inner distance and compare to the prints after the first few layers are printed. Due to different extrusion calibrations you may need to determine the % difference and scale the design to compensate for different extrusion settings that may cause tolerances to be slightly off. these are designed with tight tolerances. My V3 had more slop than I preferred though still produced little to no Z wobble on my prints. if your z screw has 1-1.5mm play you should still see an amazing improvement if your printer is suffering from z wobble prior to the upgrade.

Additional parts: 4x M3x 20 hex screws (same as whats on the printer, just longer, you will need at least 6mm longer than stock as that is the thickness of the part)

1.) print parts
2.) remove the top section of the printer
3.) loosen the triangular metal piece on post and allow to slide down the rod.
4.) install part with elongated portion facing down (note: parts are marked "L" & "R")
5.) The part should fit with little to no play but not snug. reassemble top portion, using longer screws reattach the triangular piece underneath your new printed parts and tighten to secure both rods in to place.
6.) print something awesome!

FYI: a bent z screw is a bent z screw. this parts will not cure z wobble from a bent z screw, replace with new lead screws then install this awesome upgrade.

Printer:

Maylan M150

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

20%

Notes:

These parts are mostly hidden so cosmetics are not really a concern, print them as fast or as slow as you like. Just be sure to compare measurements of your printer rods and the parts prior to disassembling in case some scaling is needed. You can save having to reassemble/disassemble your printer more than once. A little slop in the z screw hole can still provide significant improvements as I saw in my earlier versions of this part. Ideally this should fit any Maylan M150 printer and possibly the wanhoo i3 as well. Additionally you can loosen the z screw nut on the carriage after reassembling your printer to relieve any tension that may be on the z screw after installing the parts, this should also help to realign the z screw and improve print quality.

comments.text: FYI: Not to put you or your design down but the leadscrews are supposed to be free at the top as to not transfer any forces to the z-axis when turning. The smooth rods job is to keep it straight. Adding this is by design a bad idea :/
comments.author: Ghostface

author: SkyNerd

description.text:
R.O.B. parts are relatively expensive in this current period. So I have created the first reproduction Gyro designed for use with R.O.B. theoretically, it should work just fine, however, the Gyro MAY be to light to be used with the spinner. I uploaded a second version in which you can glue M8 washers to add extra weight to the Gyro. Version 1 is the first variation that does not use any extra weights. Version 4 (2 and 3 didn't quite work out) uses washers in the center for extra weight so it will work with the Gyro Spinner as version 1 was too light. The two variations of the pt2 are practically the same, except version 2 uses more of a edge blend on the top. Both versions are available in case the edge blend causes problems.

To build one, you will need the following:
1 m3 screw that is at around 35mm long.
2 washers that have a 50mm diameter and a 14mm inner hole diameter. It also has to be approximately 1mm thick.

A quick note, I would recommend printing at 100% infill to add the extra weight. if version 1 doesn't work with your spinner, print the heavier version 4. Another note, don't screw the m3 in all the way, otherwise it will not spin correctly.
It's a toy drumstick I made for my kids.

description.text:
This is a battery mount for this type of battery pack:
https://www.amazon.com/Duratrax-5000mAh-Battery-Standard-Connector/dp/B004AF88K0/

It's a snug fit for both the battery as well as the cover. The cover in fact was supposed to be hinged but with the sizes involved it ends up snapping into place with a firm push and staying there which I was fine with. I've countersunk the bolt holes countersunk for better clearance. The battery stays in there pretty tight and is not meant to be taken in and out frequently because you need to slide something down the sides and get a good grip before you can bring them out.

I plan on recharging the batteries once they're inside by hooking up them up to the charger and then inserting the charger's thermometer inside the box so that it's touching the battery snugly.

description.text:
This is a remix of AndrewBougie`s Scifi Small Part Storage Crates. You can see the original here.

I wanted one big drawer that was stackable with the smaller drawer modules. I used calipers to get all the dimensions, but the parts are interchangeable with the originals without issue. Upon closer inspection, it looks as though the original bases have a chamfer around the front while mine does not but it is barely noticeable. I also included my versions of the drawers without dividers although I think they`re now included if you download directly from the original page.
